qas.question: What is a more fuel efficient way for STOVL aircraft to take off rather than vertically?

answers.text: using the ramp and a running start

qas.question: What kind of aircraft are capable of taking off vertically?
What landing aircraft have removed the need for arresting cables?
What do Russian carriers include for launching lightly loaded conventional fighters?
What do Russian carriers still use to recover?

answers.text: traditional carrier arresting cables and a tailhook on their aircraft

plausible_answers.text: using the ramp and a running start

qas.question: What is a less fuel efficient way for STOVL aircraft to take off rather than vertically?
What kind of aircraft are capable of taking off horizontally?
What landing aircraft have included the need for arresting cables?
What do Russian carriers include for launching heavily loaded conventional fighters?

plausible_answers.text: traditional carrier arresting cables and a tailhook on their aircraft

qas.question: What do Russian carriers no longer use to recover?

context: Although <a1_0><b6_0>STOVL<b6_0/><a1_0/> aircraft are capable of taking off vertically from a spot on the deck, <a0_0><b5_0>using the ramp and a running start<b5_0/><a0_0/> is far more fuel efficient and permits a heavier launch weight. As catapults are unnecessary, carriers with this arrangement reduce weight, complexity, and space needed for complex steam or electromagnetic launching equipment, <a2_0><b7_0>vertical<b7_0/><a2_0/> landing aircraft also remove the need for arresting cables and related hardware. Russian, Chinese, and future Indian carriers include <a3_0><b8_0>a ski-jump ramp<b8_0/><a3_0/> for launching lightly loaded conventional fighter aircraft but recover using <a4_0><b9_0>traditional carrier arresting cables and a tailhook on their aircraft<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
